attributes.title: How do people with chronic low back pain perceive interventions that target the brain to reduce pain and disability?
attributes.description: How do people with chronic low back pain perceive interventions that target the brain to reduce pain and disability? We will conduct a qualitative study to understand people's experience in treatments intended to target the brain for chronic low back pain.

q1.value: How do people with chronic low back pain perceive interventions that target the brain to reduce pain and disability?

q2.value: Rodrigo Rizzo, Benedict Martin Wand, Hayley B Leake, Samantha Bunzli, Adrian Traeger, James McAuley

q3.value:
Chronic low back pain (CLBP) is responsible for the largest direct and indirect costs associated with low back pain (Lin 2011). Most interventions for CLBP offer minimal clinically meaningful improvements in pain and disability (Henschke et al. 2010, Chou et al. 2017a, Chou et al. 2017b) and some interventions have harmful side effects (Abdel Shaheed et al. 2016). Novel treatments are needed to move the field forward. 

There has been a shift in focus towards exploring the brain of people in pain. Research has identified neurochemical, structural and functional changes in the brains of patients with chronic low back pain compared to people without pain (Wand et al. 2011). Many studies have shown the influence of beliefs, expectations, contextual factors, cognitive, and emotional regulation in the experience of pain which can, at least in part, be modulated by experimental conditions or interventions (Matthewson et al. 2019, Koban et al. 2019). These findings have encouraged researchers to develop new treatments for the management of CLBP (Moseley 2016). Bagg et al. (2017) conducted a randomized controlled trial (RESOLVE) which assessed the efficacy of a graded rehabilitation programme for people with CLBP. In this trial, patients received a package of strategies that are thought to target central nervous dysfunction (Bagg et al. 2017), including pain education, sensory discriminative training, graded motor imagery, mirror visual feedback and movement training (Bagg et al. 2017). It is possible that many of the therapies in the RESOLVE are unfamiliar for patients with CLBP. Treatment beliefs have been associated with treatment choice (Dima et al. 2015), and several barriers have been identified for treatment of low back pain such as lack of discussion about self-management; unrecognition of the emotional impact of pain in patients ‘life; and characteristics of treatment organization (Gordon et al. 2017). Participants of the RESOLVE-trial could provide valuable information about their experience in receiving interventions designed to target the brain instead of targeting the structure of the back.

Qualitative research is the optimal design to understand the patient experience, offering rich and compelling insights into the real-world experiences and perspectives of patients (Braun and Clarke 2014). There are no qualitative studies exploring the patients` perception of interventions intended explicitly to target the function of the brain to manage CLBP. We will conduct a qualitative study to understand patients' experiences and perceptions of interventions that target the brain for the management of chronic low back pain. Also, we want to understand patients' experiences and perceptions about a rehabilitation program aimed to their brain for the management of chronic low back pain.

q4.value: In this study, we will use an inductive orientation to explore people`s perception about their experience. For this reason, we do not have a hypothesis for the study.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

q7.value: The interviewer did not have any pre-existing relationship with participants. The interviewer will not have information if patients are responders or non-responders to treatment during the interview.

question.value: This study will be a qualitative study using the approach of reflexive thematic analysis described by Braun and Clarke (Braun and Clarke 2006). In this study, we will use an inductive orientation to explore people`s perception of their experience. We will develop an interactive data collection method, using semi-structured interviews. The semi-structured interview was developed to enable a flexible and fluid approach and facilitate the emergence of themes and topics related to participants’ own experiences and points of view.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

q11.value: Personal information about patients will be given by the research manager. All other data will be collected latter.

question.value:
We will categorize participants from the RESOLVE trial into responders (more than 2 points reduction in pain intensity on the Pain Numerical Rating Scale – PNRS, 0-10) and non-responders (less than 2 points reduction on the PNRS, 0-10) measured at the primary outcome of the trial (18 weeks post randomization). In addition, we will select a diverse sample in terms of age, sex and baseline characteristics of pain and disability, to obtain a wide range of viewpoints. The interviewers and analysers will be blinded to responder status of the participants during the process of interviews, transcriptions and analysis. We will use a convenience sample from these 2 groups to construct our study sample. We will contact participants after treatment in the RESOLVE trial and invite them to participate in this study.

The first author (RR) will conduct individuals interviews by telephone. We will use the land telephone at Neuroscience Research Australia (NeuRA, 139 Barker St, Randwick NSW 2031). All conversations will be audio-recorded with two recorder devices. The interviewer did not have any pre-existing relationship with participants. The interviewer did not have information if patients are responders or non-responders to treatment during the interview. We will transcribe interviews using automated transcription software (speechmatics.com). We will read automated transcriptions while listening to the audios and make adjustment of the transcription manually if necessary. Interviews transcripts will be anonymized and entered into QRS International’s NVivo 10 qualitative data analysis software (https://www.qsrinternational.com/nvivo/home).

q13.value: Sample size will be determined using inductive thematic saturation.

q14.value: Sample size will be determined using inductive thematic saturation. The justification of using saturation principle is that the data collection is an iterative process with data analysis. The results of the study are governed by emerging information rather than predefined characteristics of the population (Vasileiou et a., 2018)

q15.value: We will interview and analyse data from participants until reaching the point where new information does not add anything to the overall story (Saunders et al. 2018).

question.value: We will interview people with chronic low back pain to understand patients' experiences and perceptions of interventions that target the brain for the management of chronic low back pain. Also, we will interview patients who participated in the RESOLVE trial to understand their experiences and perceptions about the program which aimed to target the brain for the management of chronic low back pain.

The first author (RR) will conduct individuals interviews by telephone. We will use the land telephone at Neuroscience Research Australia (NeuRA, 139 Barker St, Randwick NSW 2031). All conversations will be audio-recorded with two recorder devices. The interviewer did not have any pre-existing relationship with participants. The interviewer did not have information if patients are responders or non-responders to treatment during the interview. We will transcribe interviews using automated transcription software (speechmatics.com). We will read automated transcriptions while listening to the audios and make adjustment of the transcription manually if necessary. Interviews transcripts will be anonymized and entered into QRS International’s NVivo 10 qualitative data analysis software (https://www.qsrinternational.com/nvivo/home).

Our analysis will follow the six-phase process of the thematic analysis described by Braun & Clarke (Braun and Clarke 2006). Analytical phases in reflexive inductive thematic analysis comprise of: (1) data familiarization (listening to the interview and reading the transcripts), (2) generating initial codes in a systematic fashion, (3) theming (reading coding reports, identifying the recurring patterns in the data), (4) reviewing/refining themes, (5) writing descriptions of individual themes and their titles, (6) writing-up the study.
Phase 1: All files (i.e., audio raw data) will receive a unique identifier to represent the participant followed by the reviewer`s name, document type and date originally created. Raw data will be stored in a central repository (a secure network location with folders for each type of raw data). We will use the speechmetics.com software to transcribe the raw data. We will read automated transcriptions while listen to the interviews and make adjustment of the transcription manually in the Microsoft Word document. We will upload the final transcription document to the software NVivo (version 12) for analysis. During all data collection, we will use an Excel spreadsheet to detail the team’s progress.
Phase 2: In NVivo, we will read through the entire data set at least once before beginning coding. We will start the production of codes from the data that relate to a theme and phenomena. We will give explicit boundaries for the codes, ensuring they are not interchangeable or redundant.
Phase 3: We will collate all the potentially relevant coded data extracts into themes using an inductive approach (i.e. codes are driven from the data, rather than trying to fit them into a pre-existing coding frame or the researcher’s analytic preconceptions). We will create a “miscellaneous” theme to temporarily house the codes that do not fit into main themes. At this stage, we will not abandon data or codes.
Phase 4: We will read the themes and determine whether the themes accurately reflect the meanings. If necessary, inadequacies in the initial coding and themes will be changed (e.g. deleting overlap codes and themes that do not have enough data, insert new codes, combining codes with same meaning).
Phase 5: We will determine the aspect of data that each theme captures and compare the themes with our original question to identify the narrative that each theme communicates. We will change names of themes to ensure that the words of participants are used in the names.
Phase 6: We will use a consolidated criteria for reporting qualitative research (COREQ)(Tong, Sainsbury and Craig 2007) reporting guidelines to ensure that we transparently detailed the methods used to achieve our findings. We will report direct quotes from participants that are illustrative of each theme.

q25.value: Participants will provide verbal consent at the time of interview. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki. We will submit the protocol for approval by the Research Ethics Approval Committee of the University of New South Wales (UNSW).

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value: Identity, Safety, and Context: The role of sociopolitical context on feelings of safety, belonging, and control

other.value: I will also conduct exploratory analyses for the following variables: I will measure whether Latinx students in different conditions report lower identity integration according to the Bicultural identity integration scale.

sample.value: I will recruit at least 420 participants and no more than 500 for a total of 70 participants per cell to detect a small to medium effect size based on a G*Power analyses.

analyses.value: I will conduct a 3 (Condition: ICE, Home Invasion, Control) x 2 (Participant Race: White, non-White Latinx) Factorial ANOVA test. I will control for identity centrality and political affiliation. I will use contrast codes to test the specific comparisons of the hypotheses.

outliers.value: I will exclude participants for the following reasons: failure on attention check or manipulation check.

dependent.value:
The Key Dependent Variables include: Sense of Safety, Sense of Control, Sense of Belonging, and accuracy and timing for the Stroop Task

Sense of Safety will be measured with a 6 item scale. (1-Strongly Disagree to 7-strongly Agree)
Sense of control will be measured with a 13-item scale (1-Strongly Disagree to 7-strongly Agree)
Sense of belonging will be measured by 2 different scales assessing national identity (3-item scale), belonging uncertainty (school based; 3-item scale)

conditions.value:
There will be 3 conditions: 
1) Control Condition- Where participants are not exposed to read any article
2) Home Invasion Condition- Where participants are exposed to an article about increasing rates of Home invasions nationally on non-specific 
3) ICE Raid Condition- Where participants are exposed to an article about increasing rates of ICE Raids targeting undocumented immigrants

hypothesis.value:
Latinx Participants in the ICE Raid condition are more likely than their White counterparts in the same condition to report lower feelings of safety (for themselves or their families), lower feelings of control and belonging, and perform worse on the Stroop task. 

Latinx participants in the ICE raid condition will report lower feelings of safety, belonging, and control relative to their Latinx participants in either the Home Invasions condition or the Control condition. They will also perform worse on the Stroop task relative to their counterparts in the other conditions.

attributes.title: Effectiveness of N95 Respirators vs Medical Masks for Influenza Prevention Among Health Care Workers

q1.value: Effectiveness of N95 Respirators vs Surgical Masks for Prevention of Acute Respiratory Infection Among Health Care Workers

q3.value: An outbreak of Novel Coronavirus in Wuhan, China draw global attention. Owing to the controversy of wearing neither N95 or surgical mask for preventing acute respiratory infection, we conducted a systemic review and meta-analysis of randomized-controlled trials in order to elucidate the effectiveness of which mask is better for prevention.

q4.value: Due to the evidence existing throughout reviewing articles, we hypothesis that there may be no difference comparing N95 versus surgical mask for preventing acute respiratory infection

q5.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: Personnel who analyze the data collected from the study are not aware of the treatment applied to any given group.

question.value:
We follow Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Reviews and Meta-analysis statement and the Cochrane Handbook for Systematic Reviews of Interventions to guide our performance of this article.
We systemically searched Medline, Embase, and the Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials (CENTRAL) for relevant published randomized controlled trials.

q10.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

question.value: Only randomized controlled trials that compared N95 repirators to Surgical mask were included. No age restriction was designated. We excluded studies not published in English or Chinese, and also those consisted of unavailable study data.

q13.value: We systemically searched Medline, Embase, and the Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials (CENTRAL) for relevant published randomized controlled trials.

question.value:
Outcome measures:
Odds ratio of clinical respiratory illness, influenza-like illness, laboratory-confirmed respiratory infection, laboratory-confirmed influenza

Review Manager Version 5.3 (The Cochrane Collaboration, Software Update, Oxford, UK) is used for the entire statistical analyses. The baseline characteristics and available data of each article were evaluated and extracted separately by two investigators. The random-effects model was selected for the main outcomes.

q21.value:
Risk of bias assessment
Two reviewers independently assessed the risk of bias using the modified Cochrane risk of bias instrument, which deals with seven domains (random sequence generation, allocation concealment, blinding of study participants, detection bias, attrition bias, reporting bias, and other bias).
GRADE (Grading of Recommendations, Assessment, Development, and Evaluation) approach are conducted that classifies evidence as a high, moderate, low, or very low quality based on considerations of risk of bias, consistency, directness, precision, and publication bias. Summaries are generated using the GRADEproGDT platform.

attributes.title: Community Mobilization during the Civil War in Nepal

q1.value: Community Mobilization during the Civil War in Nepal

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: This study considers whether pre-existing, non-state social capital (in the form of informal governance capacity) is able to mitigate any of the damage caused to communities during conflict. To test this, I look for associations between institutional capacity and a number of outcomes that operationalize damage to the community. This study is observational, and relies upon a novel combination of pre-existing data from Nepal.

q16.value: I operationalize social capital as the density and durability of "forest user groups" within individual village development committees (VDC), the most local level of Nepali governance. I calculate the proportion of households and hectares under informal but organized forest management before and during the war. I also operationalize the involvement of marginalized groups in local governance as the percentage of women on the boards of each VDC's forest user groups. My main dependent variable is civilian casualties caused by Maoist rebels. I also attempt to measure the change in the number of minorities living in each VDC before and after the war and the income and development in each VDC before and after the war. Data allowing, I hope to consider displacement and other civilian abuse. Speaking broadly, I expect both high density of forest groups and high inclusivity within forest groups to relate negatively to casualties, and positively to changes in income and diversity (where lower values for this change indicate a reduction in either). These finding would support the main theoretical expectation that local governance allows civilians to credibly bargain with rebel groups. I also predict that density of forest, and density of forest user groups, will relate positively to the amount of insurgent activity in the area. That is, I expect that forest user groups will prevent civilian abuse even as they encourage insurgents to colocate in those communities. If these results obtain, I will argue they evidence a deepening mutual reliance that occurs only in communities with substantial social capital.

q17.value: I will test these hypotheses by combining pre-existing data from five sources, and through the original coding of two further variables. Information on community demographics and development will come from the Nepal's 2001 and 2011 census and from the World Bank's Nepal Living Standards Surveys in 1995 and 2006. Both surveys are coded to the VDC level. Information on civilian casualties will be obtain by cross-checking and verifying reports in the ACLED database with reports gathered by the Informal Services Sector, a well-respecting Nepali think tank. Data on forest user groups is available from Nepal's Department of Forestry. I also plan to determine whether and for how long each VDC hosted combat between Maoist rebels and the Nepalese state, and the amount of forest cover in each VDC.

That is, I expect that forest user groups will prevent civilian abuse even as they encourage insurgents to colocate in those communities. If these results obtain, I will argue they evidence a deepening mutual reliance that occurs only in communities with substantial social capital.
registration_responses.q17: I will test these hypotheses by combining pre-existing data from five sources, and through the original coding of two further variables. Information on community demographics and development will come from the Nepal's 2001 and 2011 census and from the World Bank's Nepal Living Standards Surveys in 1995 and 2006. Both surveys are coded to the VDC level. Information on civilian casualties will be obtain by cross-checking and verifying reports in the ACLED database with reports gathered by the Informal Services Sector, a well-respecting Nepali think tank. Data on forest user groups is available from Nepal's Department of Forestry. I also plan to determine whether and for how long each VDC hosted combat between Maoist rebels and the Nepalese state, and the amount of forest cover in each VDC.

attributes.title: Individual trajectories of psychological symptoms and resilience outcomes in children exposed to traumatic events in humanitarian settings in low- and middle-income countries
attributes.description: There are few longitudinal investigations that have explored the natural course of psychological symptoms over time and the effect of the exposure to multiple types of trauma in children exposed to war/conflict and not receiving psychosocial interventions. An important opportunity to understand the longitudinal trajectories of mental health and psychosocial wellbeing of conflict-affected children concerns the analysis of control groups in intervention studies. In this study, we aim to take advantage of a series of four cluster randomized trials with identical design that focused on a classroom-based intervention with conflict-affected children in Burundi, Indonesia, Nepal, and Sri Lanka. In the present project we aim to analyze: 1) the different directions that children responses to conflict-related events may take in terms of psychological symptoms and resilience outcomes over time; 2) the impact of the number of types of traumatic events on psychological symptoms and resilience outcomes over time.

q1.value: Longitudinal impacts of conflict-events and daily stressors on psychosocial outcomes of children in low- and middle-income countries

q2.value: Marianna Purgato, Federico Tedeschi, Wietse A Tol, Corrado Barbui

q3.value:
It is widely acknowledged that the exposure to conflict-related events (i.e., reporting exposure to physical and psychological violence, torture, bombings and other war-related events) may have an impact on the psychological status of children living in humanitarian settings in low- and middle-income countries (LAMIC). Exposure to conflict-related events may generate a wide range of consequences, from the increase of mental health issues and/or log-term psychopathology, to positive effects like the capacity to cope with adversities1,2. Practitioners working in humanitarian settings involving armed conflicts or natural disasters observed that despite exposure to extreme forms of adversities, the majority of children do not exhibit Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD) or other clinical problems3,4. 
According to this premise, an analysis of the different directions that children responses to conflict-related events may take is useful to orient research and clinical practice5 towards the choice of the most appropriate intervention for increasing child wellbeing. The majority of research so far has focused on conflict-related events and subsequent psychopathology, while far less research has explored the role of variables associated with resilience outcomes6. Deficit approaches frequently pathologize war-affected people, focusing on problems instead of recognizing resources, strengths, and abilities to cope and navigate complex environments3,6,7. A longitudinal analysis of the natural response to conflict-related events will provide inputs about the use of resilience-based approaches in humanitarian settings.

q4.value: We hypothesize that exposure to conflict-related events had an impact on psychological symptoms, functional impairment, and resilience outcomes in children living in humanitarian settings in LAMICs

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
We will use an individual participant database with repeated observations of a large sample of children followed-up for a period of six months. We refer to Purgato et al. (2018)8,9 for a detailed description of the full methodology that has been adopted to develop the dataset. 
In the current study, we will explore the probability of a child exposed to specific conflict-related event(s) to worsen symptoms level of post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD), depression, and anxiety, or, to spontaneously increase resilience outcomes. We will develop a model taking into consideration observed and unobserved confounders at both individual and group level.

We will develop a model taking into consideration observed and unobserved confounders at both individual and group level.  

The pathway models that we aim to test are:
1a. a relationship between the number and type of conflict-related events and psychological symptoms and functional impairment over time;
1b. a relationship between the number and type of conflict-related events and resilience outcomes over time.

The predictor measures will be dichotomous variables . We will test hypotheses using both unadjusted and adjusted models. Age, gender, and country will be added simultaneously into the adjusted model. 
To understand how the exposure to risk factors influence outcomes over time, we will adopt the cross-lagged regression model . This model is intended to analyse longitudinal data where each observation or person is recorded at multiple points in time16. The models are considered "crossed" because they estimate relationships from one variable to another and vice-versa. They are considered "lagged" because they estimate relationships between variables across different time points. Taken together, cross-lagged panel models estimate the directional influence variables have on each other over time. The primary goal of cross-lagged panel models is to examine the causal influences between variables
We will use the software programs R 3.5.017 and Stata 15.118 for data synthesis.

attributes.title: Longitudinal associations between collective narcissism, secure in-group identification, SDO and RWA

q1.value: Longitudinal associations between collective narcissism, secure in-group identification, SDO and RWA

q2.value: Paulina Górska, Marta Marchlewska, Anna Stefaniak, Katarzyna Malinowska, Katarzyna Lipowska, Zuzanna Molenda

q3.value:
Past research revealed that collective narcissism is positively related to both RWA and SDO (Golec et al., 2009; Golec et al., 2013; Górska et al., 2019). At the same time, findings regarding the relationship between in-group identification and ideological beliefs seem to be less consistent. Specifically, while in-group identification tends to correlate positively with RWA (Golec et al., 2009; Golec et al., 2013; Górska et al., 2019), its association with SDO ranges from r = -.18 (Golec et al., 2013; Study 3) to r = .33 (Golec et al., 2009; Study 1). 

Importantly, none of the past research examined whether ideological attitudes are the antecedent or the consequence of narcissistic and non-narcissistic in-group identification. Even if RWA and SDO were assessed in the past studies, they were treated as the covariates of collective narcissism and secure in-group identification. Moreover, past research used solely cross-sectional design, which did not allow for observing the relations of interest over time. In this project, we aim to check the longitudinal associations between the two modes of in-group identification and ideological beliefs. To this end, we will use data from two two-wave surveys conducted in the population of adult Poles. The current pre-registration concerns Study 2. 

In the following paragraphs, we propose that ideological beliefs may be considered both as the antecedents and the consequences of narcissistic and non-narcissistic in-group identification. We begin with presenting theoretical and empirical arguments in favor of Ideological-attitudes-as-antecedents hypothesis, and then present the points supporting ideological-beliefs-as-consequences hypothesis. Next, we report the results of Study 1 – an initial attempt to test our predictions. 

Ideological attitudes as antecedens 

	Dual Process Model (Duckitt, 2001) proposes that intergroup attitudes are driven by two independent processes. One of these processes stems from punitive socialization and is associated with perceiving the world as a dangerous place and compliance to in-group norms. The other one, in turn, originates from unaffectionate child-rearing and entails viewing the world as a competitive jungle where the strong win and the weak loose. These two distinct perspectives on the world lead to the development of RWA and SDO, respectively.

	As RWA and SDO are rooted in different motives (threat and dominance, respectively), they predict distinct outcomes. For instance, while RWA predicts negative attitudes toward groups that threaten social order, SDO is associated with prejudice toward groups located at the bottom of social hierarchy (Asbrock, Sibley, & Duckitt, 2010). In-group identification mode may constitute yet another consequence of RWA and SDO. Specifically, high SDO individuals may be inclined to perceive their in-group as placed at the top of intergroup hierarchy. This motivation may be satisfied by collective narcissism, which encompasses viewing one’s in-group as exceptional and entitled to privileged treatment (even if unrecognized). As such, it is reasonable to expect a positive over-time effect of SDO on collective narcissism (S1H1).  By contrast, non-narcissistic in-group identification, which encompasses positive yet critical views of one’s group and elicits positive behavior toward low-status groups (Górska et al., in press), remains in conflict with domination motive. Therefore, SDO should predict it negatively (S1H2). When RWA is concerned, it is reasonable to expect a positive effect of this variable on collective narcissism (S1H3). This is because both RWA and collective narcissism are associated with constant vigilance and a sense of threat. Moreover, in social contexts where the dominant discourse promotes grandiose in-group image, concern for social cohesion reflected in RWA may prompt the adoption of narcissistic in-group identification. At the same time, RWA may serve as the positive predictor of non-narcissistic identification with one’s group (S1H4). Compliance to social norms and tradition may translate into in-group attachment, which is accompanied by positive attitudes toward different groups. Indeed, past research found that, in contrast to SDO, RWA might predict positive out-group attitudes if negative attitudes are perceived as the violation of existing norms (Bilewicz, Soral, Marchlewska, & Winiewski, 2017; Roets, Au, & van Hiel, 2015). When we combine the hypotheses mentioned above, we can expect that SDO and RWA should exert opposite effects on non-narcissistic in-group identification (S1H5), while their effects on collective narcissism should be similar. 
	
Ideological attitudes as consequences 
	
Although rarely explored in the literature (see Osborne, Milojev, & Sibley, 2017), viewing SDO and RWA as the consequences of different modes of in-group identification is also theoretically viable. Specifically, belief in the extraordinary greatness of one’s group (collective narcissism) may prompt the support for intergroup hierarchy, at least for members of  high- or average-status groups (S1H6). This, in turn, may lead to prejudice toward the disadvantaged. As shown in the past research, collective narcissism predicts hostility toward low-status groups such immigrants (Golec de Zavala, Cichocka, & Bilewicz, 2016) or Muslims and Syrian refugees (Dyduch-Hazar, Mrozinski, Golec de Zavala, 2019). On the other hand, the constant sense of threat embedded in collective narcissism (e.g., Cichocka & Golec de Zavala, 2012; Golec de Zavala, Cichocka, Iskra-Golec, 2013) may lead to adoption of RWA, which builds upon the need for safety (S1H7). Regarding non-narcissistic in-group identification, one may expect that this variable would have a negative over-time effect on SDO (S1H8). Secure attachment to one’s group, which entails lower prejudice, may inoculate against explicitly hostile ideologies such as support for intergroup hierarchy. At the same time, non-narcissistic in-group identification seems likely to elicit adherence to social norms (especially the norm of tolerance), and, as such, may increase RWA over time (S1H9). Summing up, while narcissistic and non-narcissistic should exert opposite effects on SDO (S1H10), their effects on RWA may be similar.  

Hypotheses in Study 1

S1H1. SDO is a positive over-time predictor of collective narcissism.

S1H2. SDO is a negative over-time predictor of non-narcissistic in-group identification.

S1H3. RWA is a positive over-time predictor of collective narcissism.

S1H4. RWA is a positive over-time predictor of non-narcissistic in-group identification.

S1H5. The difference between RWA and SDO over-time effects on non-narcissistic in-group identification is significant
 
S1H6. Collective narcissism is a positive over-time predictor of SDO.

S1H7. Collective narcissism is a positive over-time predictor of RWA.

S1H8. Non-narcissistic in-group identification is a negative over-time predictor of SDO.

S1H9. Non-narcissistic in-group identification is a positive over-time predictor of RWA.

S1H10. The difference between collective narcissism and non-narcissistic in-group identification over-time effects on SDO is significant.

Study 1: Method 

To verify our hypotheses, we conducted a two-wave longitudinal survey of Poles (Study 1; N = 599). Study 1 used Computer-Assisted Personal Interviews and a 6-month interval between the measurements. Participants of Wave 1 (N = 1,000) constituted a representative sample of adult Poles. Among other variables, the questionnaire included the measures of SDO, RWA, nation-based collective narcissism and in-group identification, individual narcissism, and individual self-esteem. Table 1 presents descriptive statistics and correlations for the variables assessed in Study 1. 

We verified our hypotheses using SEM with ML estimator. While RWA, SDO, collective narcissism and in-group identification were specified as latent variables, individual narcissism and self-esteem served as observed variables. To improve the fit of estimated models, we created item parcels for RWA, SDA, individual narcissism and in-group identification prior to main analyses. 

After concluding scalar variance, we estimated four autoregressive cross-lagged panel models. These models differed along two dimensions – the number of included variables and the treatment of T2 latent variables. First, while two models (Figures 1 and 2) involved only latent variables (i.e., RWA, SDO, collective narcissism, and in-group identification), the other two (Figures 3 and 4) included six variables (latent variables plus individual narcissism and self-esteem as observed variables). Controlling for individual narcissism and self-esteem was aimed to test the robustness of our conclusions, as these variables had been demonstrated to correlate with the two modes of in-group identification (e.g., Golec de Zavala et al., 2009, 2019), as well as ideological beliefs (Cichocka et al., 2017).  Second, the analyses differed with regard to the way, in which T2 latent variables were defined. Specifically, next to conventional autoregressive cross-lagged panel models (Figures 1 and 3) we tested models accounting for the overlap between the measures of RWA and SDO, as well as collective narcissism and in-group identification (Figures 2 and 4). We assumed that by covarying-out the variances shared with counterpart variables, we would be more successful in capturing unique components of RWA, SDO, collective narcissism and in-group identification (see Cichocka et al., 2017; Golec de Zavala et al., 2013). Importantly, the fit of models with the equal number of variables was identical. 

Regarding our hypotheses,  only  part of them received support across all tested models (Table 2).  Specifically,  SDO was a negative over-time predictor of non-narcissistic  in-group identification (S1H2), the longitudinal effects of RWA and SDO on non-narcissistic in-group identification differed significantly (S1H5), collective narcissism was a positive over-time predictor of collective narcissism (S1H6), non-narcissistic in-group identification exerted a negative effect on (S1H8), and the effects of two different types of in-group identification had opposite effects on SDO (S1H10). 

Post-hoc power analyses using Monte Carlo simulations (10,000 each) showed that Study 1 was underpowered to detect the effects supporting S1H3, S1H4, S1H7, and S1H9 (Table 3). At the same time, the final sample size (N = 599) was rather high as for a two-wave study in social and personality psychology, which suggests that the effects corresponding to S1H3, S1H4, S1H7, and S1H9 were trivial.  

In conclusion, it seems that this was SDO (but not necessarily RWA) that  decided whether  high-status group members adopted narcissistic or non-narcissistic identification. While high SDO individuals were likely to develop collective narcissism, low SDO predisposed to non-narcissistic identification with one’s group. In line with our expectations, RWA and SDO  differed in their longitudinal effects on  non-narcissistic in-group identification.  

The aim of Study 2 – the subject of this pre-registration – is to replicate findings obtained in Study 1 using a different set of longitudinal data coming from the same socio-political context.

q4.value:
Based on the results of power analyses reported in Table 4, we decided to test six hypotheses in Study 2:  

S2H1. SDO is a positive over-time predictor of collective narcissism.

S2H2. SDO is a negative over-time predictor of non-narcissistic in-group identification.

S2H3. The difference between RWA and SDO over-time effects on non-narcissistic in-group identification is significantl.

S2H4. Narcissistic in-group identification is a positive predictor of SDO.

S2H5. Non-narcissistic in-group identification is a negative over-time predictor of SDO.

S2H6. The difference between collective narcissism and non-narcissistic in-group identification over-time effects on SDO is significant.

While for the models accounting for the shared variance between T2 RWA and SDO we expected all of these hypotheses to be in line with the data, for conventional autoregressive cross-lagged panel model hypotheses S2H2-S2H6 should hold (see Table 4).

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: The methodology of Study 2 would be the same as in Study 1. Specifically, Study 2 would involve two measurements divided by a 6-month interval. While the data from Wave 1 are already available (data collection spanned July and August 2019), the fieldwork for Wave 2 would be completed by the end of February 2020.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Data would be collected through Computer Assisted Personal Interview conducted by interviewers from an external research company.

q13.value: As specified in a contract with an external research company, the sample will consist of at least 780 adults who took part in the representative survey of Poles conducted in July-August 2019. This number will account for 60% of the initial sample (1,300 respondents). The initial sample was sampled randomly from the population of adult Poles using PESEL sampling frame.

q14.value: Given the expected sample size in Study 2 (80%), effects observed in Study 1 (Table 1), and conventional 80% power, we performed a series of Monte Carlo power analyses (10,000 simulations each) to check whether the sample size planned for Study 2 would be sufficient to find the effects of interest. As presented in Table 4, a sample of at least 780 observations is powered enough to find the effects hypothesized in S2H1-S2H6.

q15.value: The exact sample size depends on the decisions of an external research company, which is not controlled by us.

question.value:
In Study 2, we will use exactly the same measures as in Study 1. The study questionnaire would also measure other variables (e.g. benevolent and hostile sexism), which would not be analyzed in the current study. 

1.	RWA would be assessed with six positively-worded items from the scale developed by Funke (2005): 
a)	What our country really needs instead of more “civil rights” is a good stiff done of law and order.  (Aggression)
b)	What our country really needs is a strong determined Leader which will crush the evil and set us on our right way again. (Aggression)
c)	Obedience and respect for authority are the most important values children should learn. (Submission) 
d)	The real keys to the “good life” are obedience, discipline, and virtue. (Submission)
e)	The withdrawal from tradition will turn out to be a fatal fault one day (Conventionalism)
f)	Being virtuous and law-abiding is in the long run better for us than permanently challenging the foundation of our society. (Conventionalism) 
1 = Strongly disagree, 5 = Strongly agree

2.	SDO would be assessed with five items borrowed from the scales developed by Pratto and colleagues (2013) and Jost and Thompson (2000): 
a)	It’s probably a good thing that certain groups are at the top and other groups are at the bottom.
b)	Inferior groups should stay in their place. 
c)	We should do what we can to equalize conditions for different groups. (Reverse-scored)
d)	We should push for group equality. (Reverse-scored) 
e)	Superior groups should dominate inferior groups. 
1 = Strongly disagree, 5 = Strongly agree

3.	Nationality-based collective narcissism would be assessed with a short scale developed by Golec de Zavala, Cichocka and Bilewicz (2013):
a)	If Poles had a major say in the world, the world would be a much better place 
b)	Poles deserve special treatment.
c)	Not many people seem to fully understand the importance of Poles. 
d)	I will never be satisfied until Poles get all they deserve. 
e)	It really makes me angry when others criticize Poles. 
1 = Strongly agree, 5 = Strongly disagree

4.	Nationality-based in-group identification would be assessed with three items borrowed from the scale developed by Cameron (2004):
a)	I feel strong ties to other Poles (In-group ties)
b)	In general, being a Pole is an important part of my self-image (Centrality)
c)	Generally, I feel good when I think of myself as a Pole (In-group affect)
1 = Strongly agree, 5 = Strongly disagree

5.	Individual narcissism would be measured with the Single Item Narcissism Scale (Konrath, Meier, & Bushman, 2014): 
To what extent do you agree with this statement? “I am a narcissist”. (Note: The word “narcissist” means egotistical, self-focused, and vain.)
1 = Not very true of me,  7 = Very true of me  

6.	Self-esteem would be assessed with the Single-Item Self-Esteem Scale (Robins, Hendin, & Trzesniewski, 2001):
To what extent do you agree with this statement? “I have high self-esteem”
1 = Not very true of me, 7 = Very true of me
The composite scores for RWA, SDO, collective narcissism and in-group identification would be obtained by averaging item responses.

We will test our hypotheses using SEM framework. First, we will test for measurement invariance (Meredith, 1993). To this end, we will first estimate a null model, where indicators (i.e., item parcels) of SDO, RWA, collective narcissism, and in-group identification would be independent of each other. Next, we will consecutively test for configural (similar pattern of factor loadings), metric (equal congeneric factor loadings), and scalar invariance (equal congeneric intercepts). To conclude that a given type of invariance holds, the change in CFI would have to be .01 or less (Cheung & Rensvold, 2002).

Like in Study 1, we will test four models differing on two dimensions – the number of included variables (4 vs. 6) and the treatment of T2 latent variables (conventional autoregressive cross-lagged models vs. models accounting for the variance shared between RWA and SDO, as well as collective narcissism and in-group identification.

q20.value: Prior to performing any SEM analyses, we will create item parcels in accordance with the balancing approach (Little, 2013). Specifically, we will create three parcels (two items each) for RWA, two parcels for SDO (three and two items, respectively), two parcels for collective narcissism (three and two items each) and two parcels for in-group identification (two and one item, respectively). Using item parcels as opposed to items would allow us to increase the cases-to-parameters ratio and lower the probability of dual loadings or correlated errors. Since we will handle longitudinal data, the selection of items to parcels would be the same across both measurements.

q21.value: To conclude satisfactory model fit, we will use standard criteria: CFI ≥ .95, RMSEA ≤ .06, SRMR ≤ .08 (Hu & Bentler, 1999). For single paths, we will use conventional p < .05 cut off value.

q22.value:
We do not plan any data exclusions. We will employ two ways of handling outliers (Aguinis, Gottfredson, & Joo, 2013):
1)	after detecting outliers (i.e., observations with Cook’s D > 1), we will remove them and re-run the analyses
2)	we will re-estimate our models using bootstrapping (5,000 re-samples), which is a robust technique 
If employing any of these methods changes substantial findings, we will report it in the main paper and provide alternative estimates in the Online Supplement.

q23.value: Missing data would be accounted for by Full Information ML.

q25.value:

registration_responses.q1: Longitudinal associations between collective narcissism, secure in-group identification, SDO and RWA
registration_responses.q2: Paulina Górska, Marta Marchlewska, Anna Stefaniak, Katarzyna Malinowska, Katarzyna Lipowska, Zuzanna Molenda
registration_responses.q3:
Past research revealed that collective narcissism is positively related to both RWA and SDO (Golec et al., 2009; Golec et al., 2013; Górska et al., 2019). At the same time, findings regarding the relationship between in-group identification and ideological beliefs seem to be less consistent. Specifically, while in-group identification tends to correlate positively with RWA (Golec et al., 2009; Golec et al., 2013; Górska et al., 2019), its association with SDO ranges from r = -.18 (Golec et al., 2013; Study 3) to r = .33 (Golec et al., 2009; Study 1). 

Importantly, none of the past research examined whether ideological attitudes are the antecedent or the consequence of narcissistic and non-narcissistic in-group identification. Even if RWA and SDO were assessed in the past studies, they were treated as the covariates of collective narcissism and secure in-group identification. Moreover, past research used solely cross-sectional design, which did not allow for observing the relations of interest over time. In this project, we aim to check the longitudinal associations between the two modes of in-group identification and ideological beliefs. To this end, we will use data from two two-wave surveys conducted in the population of adult Poles. The current pre-registration concerns Study 2. 

In the following paragraphs, we propose that ideological beliefs may be considered both as the antecedents and the consequences of narcissistic and non-narcissistic in-group identification. We begin with presenting theoretical and empirical arguments in favor of Ideological-attitudes-as-antecedents hypothesis, and then present the points supporting ideological-beliefs-as-consequences hypothesis. Next, we report the results of Study 1 – an initial attempt to test our predictions. 

Ideological attitudes as antecedens 

	Dual Process Model (Duckitt, 2001) proposes that intergroup attitudes are driven by two independent processes. One of these processes stems from punitive socialization and is associated with perceiving the world as a dangerous place and compliance to in-group norms. The other one, in turn, originates from unaffectionate child-rearing and entails viewing the world as a competitive jungle where the strong win and the weak loose. These two distinct perspectives on the world lead to the development of RWA and SDO, respectively.

	As RWA and SDO are rooted in different motives (threat and dominance, respectively), they predict distinct outcomes. For instance, while RWA predicts negative attitudes toward groups that threaten social order, SDO is associated with prejudice toward groups located at the bottom of social hierarchy (Asbrock, Sibley, & Duckitt, 2010). In-group identification mode may constitute yet another consequence of RWA and SDO. Specifically, high SDO individuals may be inclined to perceive their in-group as placed at the top of intergroup hierarchy. This motivation may be satisfied by collective narcissism, which encompasses viewing one’s in-group as exceptional and entitled to privileged treatment (even if unrecognized). As such, it is reasonable to expect a positive over-time effect of SDO on collective narcissism (S1H1).  By contrast, non-narcissistic in-group identification, which encompasses positive yet critical views of one’s group and elicits positive behavior toward low-status groups (Górska et al., in press), remains in conflict with domination motive. Therefore, SDO should predict it negatively (S1H2). When RWA is concerned, it is reasonable to expect a positive effect of this variable on collective narcissism (S1H3). This is because both RWA and collective narcissism are associated with constant vigilance and a sense of threat. Moreover, in social contexts where the dominant discourse promotes grandiose in-group image, concern for social cohesion reflected in RWA may prompt the adoption of narcissistic in-group identification. At the same time, RWA may serve as the positive predictor of non-narcissistic identification with one’s group (S1H4). Compliance to social norms and tradition may translate into in-group attachment, which is accompanied by positive attitudes toward different groups. Indeed, past research found that, in contrast to SDO, RWA might predict positive out-group attitudes if negative attitudes are perceived as the violation of existing norms (Bilewicz, Soral, Marchlewska, & Winiewski, 2017; Roets, Au, & van Hiel, 2015). When we combine the hypotheses mentioned above, we can expect that SDO and RWA should exert opposite effects on non-narcissistic in-group identification (S1H5), while their effects on collective narcissism should be similar. 
	
Ideological attitudes as consequences 
	
Although rarely explored in the literature (see Osborne, Milojev, & Sibley, 2017), viewing SDO and RWA as the consequences of different modes of in-group identification is also theoretically viable. Specifically, belief in the extraordinary greatness of one’s group (collective narcissism) may prompt the support for intergroup hierarchy, at least for members of  high- or average-status groups (S1H6). This, in turn, may lead to prejudice toward the disadvantaged. As shown in the past research, collective narcissism predicts hostility toward low-status groups such immigrants (Golec de Zavala, Cichocka, & Bilewicz, 2016) or Muslims and Syrian refugees (Dyduch-Hazar, Mrozinski, Golec de Zavala, 2019). On the other hand, the constant sense of threat embedded in collective narcissism (e.g., Cichocka & Golec de Zavala, 2012; Golec de Zavala, Cichocka, Iskra-Golec, 2013) may lead to adoption of RWA, which builds upon the need for safety (S1H7). Regarding non-narcissistic in-group identification, one may expect that this variable would have a negative over-time effect on SDO (S1H8). Secure attachment to one’s group, which entails lower prejudice, may inoculate against explicitly hostile ideologies such as support for intergroup hierarchy. At the same time, non-narcissistic in-group identification seems likely to elicit adherence to social norms (especially the norm of tolerance), and, as such, may increase RWA over time (S1H9). Summing up, while narcissistic and non-narcissistic should exert opposite effects on SDO (S1H10), their effects on RWA may be similar.  

Hypotheses in Study 1

S1H1. SDO is a positive over-time predictor of collective narcissism.

S1H2. SDO is a negative over-time predictor of non-narcissistic in-group identification.

S1H3. RWA is a positive over-time predictor of collective narcissism.

S1H4. RWA is a positive over-time predictor of non-narcissistic in-group identification.

S1H5. The difference between RWA and SDO over-time effects on non-narcissistic in-group identification is significant
 
S1H6. Collective narcissism is a positive over-time predictor of SDO.

S1H7. Collective narcissism is a positive over-time predictor of RWA.

S1H8. Non-narcissistic in-group identification is a negative over-time predictor of SDO.

S1H9. Non-narcissistic in-group identification is a positive over-time predictor of RWA.

S1H10. The difference between collective narcissism and non-narcissistic in-group identification over-time effects on SDO is significant.

Study 1: Method 

To verify our hypotheses, we conducted a two-wave longitudinal survey of Poles (Study 1; N = 599). Study 1 used Computer-Assisted Personal Interviews and a 6-month interval between the measurements. Participants of Wave 1 (N = 1,000) constituted a representative sample of adult Poles. Among other variables, the questionnaire included the measures of SDO, RWA, nation-based collective narcissism and in-group identification, individual narcissism, and individual self-esteem. Table 1 presents descriptive statistics and correlations for the variables assessed in Study 1. 

We verified our hypotheses using SEM with ML estimator. While RWA, SDO, collective narcissism and in-group identification were specified as latent variables, individual narcissism and self-esteem served as observed variables. To improve the fit of estimated models, we created item parcels for RWA, SDA, individual narcissism and in-group identification prior to main analyses. 

After concluding scalar variance, we estimated four autoregressive cross-lagged panel models. These models differed along two dimensions – the number of included variables and the treatment of T2 latent variables. First, while two models (Figures 1 and 2) involved only latent variables (i.e., RWA, SDO, collective narcissism, and in-group identification), the other two (Figures 3 and 4) included six variables (latent variables plus individual narcissism and self-esteem as observed variables). Controlling for individual narcissism and self-esteem was aimed to test the robustness of our conclusions, as these variables had been demonstrated to correlate with the two modes of in-group identification (e.g., Golec de Zavala et al., 2009, 2019), as well as ideological beliefs (Cichocka et al., 2017).  Second, the analyses differed with regard to the way, in which T2 latent variables were defined. Specifically, next to conventional autoregressive cross-lagged panel models (Figures 1 and 3) we tested models accounting for the overlap between the measures of RWA and SDO, as well as collective narcissism and in-group identification (Figures 2 and 4). We assumed that by covarying-out the variances shared with counterpart variables, we would be more successful in capturing unique components of RWA, SDO, collective narcissism and in-group identification (see Cichocka et al., 2017; Golec de Zavala et al., 2013). Importantly, the fit of models with the equal number of variables was identical. 

Regarding our hypotheses,  only  part of them received support across all tested models (Table 2).  Specifically,  SDO was a negative over-time predictor of non-narcissistic  in-group identification (S1H2), the longitudinal effects of RWA and SDO on non-narcissistic in-group identification differed significantly (S1H5), collective narcissism was a positive over-time predictor of collective narcissism (S1H6), non-narcissistic in-group identification exerted a negative effect on (S1H8), and the effects of two different types of in-group identification had opposite effects on SDO (S1H10). 

Post-hoc power analyses using Monte Carlo simulations (10,000 each) showed that Study 1 was underpowered to detect the effects supporting S1H3, S1H4, S1H7, and S1H9 (Table 3). At the same time, the final sample size (N = 599) was rather high as for a two-wave study in social and personality psychology, which suggests that the effects corresponding to S1H3, S1H4, S1H7, and S1H9 were trivial.  

In conclusion, it seems that this was SDO (but not necessarily RWA) that  decided whether  high-status group members adopted narcissistic or non-narcissistic identification. While high SDO individuals were likely to develop collective narcissism, low SDO predisposed to non-narcissistic identification with one’s group. In line with our expectations, RWA and SDO  differed in their longitudinal effects on  non-narcissistic in-group identification.  

The aim of Study 2 – the subject of this pre-registration – is to replicate findings obtained in Study 1 using a different set of longitudinal data coming from the same socio-political context.
registration_responses.q4:
Based on the results of power analyses reported in Table 4, we decided to test six hypotheses in Study 2:  

S2H1. SDO is a positive over-time predictor of collective narcissism.

S2H2. SDO is a negative over-time predictor of non-narcissistic in-group identification.

S2H3. The difference between RWA and SDO over-time effects on non-narcissistic in-group identification is significantl.

S2H4. Narcissistic in-group identification is a positive predictor of SDO.

S2H5. Non-narcissistic in-group identification is a negative over-time predictor of SDO.

S2H6. The difference between collective narcissism and non-narcissistic in-group identification over-time effects on SDO is significant.

While for the models accounting for the shared variance between T2 RWA and SDO we expected all of these hypotheses to be in line with the data, for conventional autoregressive cross-lagged panel model hypotheses S2H2-S2H6 should hold (see Table 4).
registration_responses.q5: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.
q6: No blinding is involved in this study.
registration_responses.q10: Registration prior to creation of data
registration_responses.q13: As specified in a contract with an external research company, the sample will consist of at least 780 adults who took part in the representative survey of Poles conducted in July-August 2019. This number will account for 60% of the initial sample (1,300 respondents). The initial sample was sampled randomly from the population of adult Poles using PESEL sampling frame.
registration_responses.q14: Given the expected sample size in Study 2 (80%), effects observed in Study 1 (Table 1), and conventional 80% power, we performed a series of Monte Carlo power analyses (10,000 simulations each) to check whether the sample size planned for Study 2 would be sufficient to find the effects of interest. As presented in Table 4, a sample of at least 780 observations is powered enough to find the effects hypothesized in S2H1-S2H6.
registration_responses.q15: The exact sample size depends on the decisions of an external research company, which is not controlled by us.
registration_responses.q20: Prior to performing any SEM analyses, we will create item parcels in accordance with the balancing approach (Little, 2013). Specifically, we will create three parcels (two items each) for RWA, two parcels for SDO (three and two items, respectively), two parcels for collective narcissism (three and two items each) and two parcels for in-group identification (two and one item, respectively). Using item parcels as opposed to items would allow us to increase the cases-to-parameters ratio and lower the probability of dual loadings or correlated errors. Since we will handle longitudinal data, the selection of items to parcels would be the same across both measurements.
registration_responses.q21: To conclude satisfactory model fit, we will use standard criteria: CFI ≥ .95, RMSEA ≤ .06, SRMR ≤ .08 (Hu & Bentler, 1999). For single paths, we will use conventional p < .05 cut off value.
registration_responses.q22:
We do not plan any data exclusions. We will employ two ways of handling outliers (Aguinis, Gottfredson, & Joo, 2013):
1)	after detecting outliers (i.e., observations with Cook’s D > 1), we will remove them and re-run the analyses
2)	we will re-estimate our models using bootstrapping (5,000 re-samples), which is a robust technique 
If employing any of these methods changes substantial findings, we will report it in the main paper and provide alternative estimates in the Online Supplement.
registration_responses.q23: Missing data would be accounted for by Full Information ML.
