registration_responses.q8.question: The methodology of Study 2 would be the same as in Study 1. Specifically, Study 2 would involve two measurements divided by a 6-month interval. While the data from Wave 1 are already available (data collection spanned July and August 2019), the fieldwork for Wave 2 would be completed by the end of February 2020.
registration_responses.q12.question: Data would be collected through Computer Assisted Personal Interview conducted by interviewers from an external research company.
registration_responses.q17.question:
In Study 2, we will use exactly the same measures as in Study 1. The study questionnaire would also measure other variables (e.g. benevolent and hostile sexism), which would not be analyzed in the current study. 

1.	RWA would be assessed with six positively-worded items from the scale developed by Funke (2005): 
a)	What our country really needs instead of more “civil rights” is a good stiff done of law and order.  (Aggression)
b)	What our country really needs is a strong determined Leader which will crush the evil and set us on our right way again. (Aggression)
c)	Obedience and respect for authority are the most important values children should learn. (Submission) 
d)	The real keys to the “good life” are obedience, discipline, and virtue. (Submission)
e)	The withdrawal from tradition will turn out to be a fatal fault one day (Conventionalism)
f)	Being virtuous and law-abiding is in the long run better for us than permanently challenging the foundation of our society. (Conventionalism) 
1 = Strongly disagree, 5 = Strongly agree

2.	SDO would be assessed with five items borrowed from the scales developed by Pratto and colleagues (2013) and Jost and Thompson (2000): 
a)	It’s probably a good thing that certain groups are at the top and other groups are at the bottom.
b)	Inferior groups should stay in their place. 
c)	We should do what we can to equalize conditions for different groups. (Reverse-scored)
d)	We should push for group equality. (Reverse-scored) 
e)	Superior groups should dominate inferior groups. 
1 = Strongly disagree, 5 = Strongly agree

3.	Nationality-based collective narcissism would be assessed with a short scale developed by Golec de Zavala, Cichocka and Bilewicz (2013):
a)	If Poles had a major say in the world, the world would be a much better place 
b)	Poles deserve special treatment.
c)	Not many people seem to fully understand the importance of Poles. 
d)	I will never be satisfied until Poles get all they deserve. 
e)	It really makes me angry when others criticize Poles. 
1 = Strongly agree, 5 = Strongly disagree

4.	Nationality-based in-group identification would be assessed with three items borrowed from the scale developed by Cameron (2004):
a)	I feel strong ties to other Poles (In-group ties)
b)	In general, being a Pole is an important part of my self-image (Centrality)
c)	Generally, I feel good when I think of myself as a Pole (In-group affect)
1 = Strongly agree, 5 = Strongly disagree

5.	Individual narcissism would be measured with the Single Item Narcissism Scale (Konrath, Meier, & Bushman, 2014): 
To what extent do you agree with this statement? “I am a narcissist”. (Note: The word “narcissist” means egotistical, self-focused, and vain.)
1 = Not very true of me,  7 = Very true of me  

6.	Self-esteem would be assessed with the Single-Item Self-Esteem Scale (Robins, Hendin, & Trzesniewski, 2001):
To what extent do you agree with this statement? “I have high self-esteem”
1 = Not very true of me, 7 = Very true of me
registration_responses.q18.question: The composite scores for RWA, SDO, collective narcissism and in-group identification would be obtained by averaging item responses.
registration_responses.q19.question:
We will test our hypotheses using SEM framework. First, we will test for measurement invariance (Meredith, 1993). To this end, we will first estimate a null model, where indicators (i.e., item parcels) of SDO, RWA, collective narcissism, and in-group identification would be independent of each other. Next, we will consecutively test for configural (similar pattern of factor loadings), metric (equal congeneric factor loadings), and scalar invariance (equal congeneric intercepts). To conclude that a given type of invariance holds, the change in CFI would have to be .01 or less (Cheung & Rensvold, 2002).

Like in Study 1, we will test four models differing on two dimensions – the number of included variables (4 vs. 6) and the treatment of T2 latent variables (conventional autoregressive cross-lagged models vs. models accounting for the variance shared between RWA and SDO, as well as collective narcissism and in-group identification.

attributes.title: Menopause Osteoporosis and Bone Intervention using Lifestyle Exercise. [MOBILE]

q1.value: Menopause Osteoporosis and Bone Intervention using Lifestyle Exercise. [MOBILE]

q3.value:
Osteoporosis is a progressive disease characterised by low bone mass and a deterioration in bone microarchitectural structure, leading to an increased susceptibility for fracture. The morbidity and mortality associated with osteoporotic fracture incur substantial social and economic costs, making osteoporosis a major public health concern (Vasikaran et al., 2011). The prevalence of osteoporosis, and associated fracture, increase substantially when women enter the menopause (Boschitsch, Durchschlag, & Dimai, 2017), owing to a significant decline in oestrogen. When oestrogen is low, RANK-L (Receptor Activator of Necrosis factor-Kappa B Ligand) expression and binding are increased, which increase bone resorption (Riggs, Khosia, & Melton, 2002). The number of women over 50 years in the UK is projected to increase (Rutherford, 2012), with most women spending more than one third of their lifetime beyond the menopausal transition (Ji & Yu, 2015). Strategies for increasing or maintaining bone health for women in the menopausal period are therefore required, in order to prevent risk of osteoporotic fracture.


Weight-bearing exercise is a non-pharmacological strategy for improving bone health and reducing osteoporosis. The osteogenic effect of exercise is mainly a result of mechanical loading on the bone (Sugiyama, Yamaguchi, & Kawai, 2002). Based on animal studies (Rubin, Sommerfeldt, Judex, & Qin, 2001), dynamic rather than static loads, high strain magnitudes/rates, rapid strain reversal and unusual frequency distributions have the greatest osteogenic effects (Ehrlich & Lanyon, 2002). Exercise that mimics these loading patterns, such as that which is dynamic and high-impact, has been found to be successful (Babatunde & Forsyth, 2013; Babatunde, Forsyth, & Gidlow, 2012). Among postmenopausal women, however, exercise interventions for improving bone health have not always been effective (Kelley & Kelley, 2006), since the exercise has not been of the right magnitude, ‘oddness’ or impact (Hannam et al., 2017). It is, therefore, important to use previously successful exercise interventions that have been carried on women who are oestrogen deplete (and therefore having a similar oestrogen status as menopausal women) and apply these to a postmenopausal population.


Aim: to examine the effect of an exercise intervention for preventing osteoporosis among postmenopausal women.


Objectives: 

To examine whether mean values for Broadband Ultrasound Attenuation (BUA) using Quantitative Ultrasound (QUS) among postmenopausal women following an eight-month exercise intervention (and at 3-month follow up), will be significantly higher than those obtained pre-intervention.


To examine whether mean BUA values among postmenopausal women following an eight-month exercise intervention (and at 3-month follow up) will be significantly higher than mean values obtained from participants in a control group undertaking sham exercises for an equivalent duration. 

To examine the feasibility of the eight-month exercise intervention for a potential larger study (larger sample size, increased number of trial arms and increased outcome measures), in terms of recruitment, adherence, perceptions, barriers, and acceptability.

q4.value: Hypotheses: Mean values for Broadband Ultrasound Attenuation (BUA) among postmenopausal women following an eight-month lifestyle intervention (consisting of dynamic, high-impact exercise) will be significantly higher than those obtained pre-intervention, and when compared to mean values obtained from participants in a sham control group.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.
Personnel who interact directly with the study subjects (either human or non-human subjects) will not be aware of the assigned treatments. (Commonly known as “double blind”)

question.value: The project will be a randomised controlled trial, investigating between and within group differences pre- and post-intervention. There will be two trial arms: an intervention group and sham control group.

q9.value: Sequel to baseline data collection and ascertainment of eligibility, participants will be randomised into either the exercise intervention group or sham-control group. Randomisation will be through computer-generation of random numbers. Participants will be blinded to group allocation.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Data will be collected at baseline, on study completion and at 3-month follow-up. Participants will be recruited from the surrounding community via email, social media posts, word of mouth, and by visits to postmenopausal social groups. Individuals who have the desired characteristics for the study will be identified and encouraged to use their social network to recruit similar participants. 

Inclusion criteria include being postmenopausal and aged ≥50 years. Postmenopause will be defined as having had an absence of menstrual cycle for 12 months or more (Hale & Burger, 2009). 

Exclusion criteria: Volunteers will be excluded from the study if they: are using any medicated that may affect bone turnover (e.g., corticosteroids, anticonvulsants, anticoagulants, calcitonin, bisphosphonates, raloxifene, denosumab and/or anabolic agents such as parathyroid hormone and growth hormone or steroids), including hormone replacement therapy and hormone-based contraception, within 6 months of starting the study; have or have had any bone, metabolic, kidney, liver, thyroid, gastro-intestinal or hormonal disorders or cancer, that may affect bone turnover; have a close family history of osteoporosis; have sustained a low trauma fragility fracture in the past 6 months; are a heavy smoking (>20 cigarettes/day) [owing to smoking being risk factor for low bone health (Yoon, Maalouf, & Sakhaee, 2012)]; if they are already undertaking bone-specific jumping exercises or equivalent exercises; if they have an existing knee, hip or back injury or have any medical condition that would prevent them from completing the exercise. These disorders and conditions will be determined based initially through verbal interview at the recruitment stage, then confirmed through the self-reported lifestyle/medical history questionnaire at baseline. Additional exclusions at baseline testing will include: a low BUA score, i.e., estimated T score of <2.5; obesity as determined by body mass index of >35 km/m2, to minimise risk of strain or injury associated with the exercise. Participants will also not be able to undertake the bone scan if they have any foot swelling, as this can make results difficult to interpret.

q13.value: A total of 134 postmenopausal women aged ≥50 years will be involved in the sample. Using actual mean and SD data from our previous study (Babatunde & Forsyth, 2014b), a total of 80 participants are required to achieve a statistical power of 0.80 to detect a significant difference in repeated measures between groups, with an effect size of 0.25 and an alpha of 0.05. To account for a possible 40% attrition rate (Bailey & Brooke-Wavell, 2011; Hooshmand et al., 2011) and still protect the required sample, considering compliance and loss to follow up in a longitudinal study of this nature, a total sample size of 134 (67 in each trial arm) will be recruited.

q14.value: A total of 134 postmenopausal women aged ≥50 years will be involved in the sample. Using actual mean and SD data from our previous study (Babatunde & Forsyth, 2014b), a total of 80 participants are required to achieve a statistical power of 0.80 to detect a significant difference in repeated measures between groups, with an effect size of 0.25 and an alpha of 0.05. To account for a possible 40% attrition rate (Bailey & Brooke-Wavell, 2011; Hooshmand et al., 2011) and still protect the required sample, considering compliance and loss to follow up in a longitudinal study of this nature, a total sample size of 134 (67 in each trial arm) will be recruited.

question.value:
Both groups (intervention and control) will complete their required programme for eight months, since 200 days (approximately 29 weeks) is the average duration of remodelling in normal trabecular bone (Eriksen, 1986), and is required for change to be detected. 

For the intervention group, participants will be required to perform 10 maximal vertical jumps, with a 10-s rest interval between each jump, using an arm swing in countermovement style on three days per week. The jumps will be performed without shoes on a hard surface. The jumps will be preceded by a warm-up lasting approximately 3 min and consisting of mobilisation exercises for the legs and lower back. The jumping protocol follows previous work in our laboratory (Babatunde & Forsyth, 2014b; Babatunde & Forsyth, 2015). Jumping will be progressed over time and in accordance with individual needs. Initially, jumping may be undertaken with the use of a handheld support (such as the back of a chair or table), should participants feel unstable. Jumps will be progressed to include multi-directional movements (jumping to the side, forwards, backwards, and diagonally). Natural progression will also occur as participants should improve their jump height with increased muscular explosiveness. Participants will be asked to fill out a simple, daily training log, stipulating when they have undertaken the exercise, in order for adherence to be assessed. 

In the control group, participants will be required to perform balance exercises. Balance is an effective treatment for avoiding falls that could potentially lead to fracture, but do not bring about a significant change in bone mineral density (de Kam et al., 2009). The balancing exercises will be progressed and varied (to ensure adherence). Initially, the use of a handheld support (such as the back of the chair) can be used. Participants will be required to balance on one leg for up to 60 seconds (2 x 60 s is equivalent in duration to the 10 jumps). This exercise will initially be progressed using time, and then by doing the following: confounding the visual fixation (e.g., head turns), changing the centre of mass (e.g. arm/leg lifts); performing the stork balance (hands on hips, knee bent and supported by standing leg); reaching in multiple directions before regaining the initial stance; closing the eyes; reducing the base of support; and a combination of these activities. The starting level of difficulty will be prescribed by the researcher, according to each participant’s functional ability. The balance exercises will be preceded by a warm-up lasting approximately 3 min and consisting of mobilisation exercises for the legs and lower back. The balance exercises are based on an existing protocol (Gianoudis et al., 2012). The purpose of the sham exercise is to foster the perception of full participation in the study, in order to decrease attrition rates, and to blind participants to the intervention. The balance exercises, although not improving bone health, could decrease the risk of fracture, making the sham control group more ethical, owing to potential improvements, and limited risks. 

To ensure quality control, digitised video clips of all exercises will be provided for the participants, who will be encouraged to perform the exercises as demonstrated on the video. The participants will be invited to one fully supervised group exercise session per month. These sessions will be used to monitor exercise quality, and to ensure progression is appropriate for each participant. Sessions will last 15-20 min. Attendance at these sessions will be monitored through registers. Apart from these supervised exercise sessions, participants will be given free choice to determine where and when they do the exercises. At the instructor-led session, training logs (Appendix 3) will be submitted. If they are unable to attend, participants will be asked to submit training logs electronically, or via post. To encourage adherence, an App will be used, which will enable weekly announcements to be posted, as well as emails and/or text reminders. Participants will be free to contact the researchers about any concerns they have during the intervention. Apart from the exercise undertaken, participants will be requested to maintain their usual exercise throughout the study. 

To improve adherence, Bandura’s Social Cognitive Theory for changing behaviour will be drawn upon. Specific constructs will include the knowledge and skills to perform the prescribed intervention, personal regulation of goal-directed health behaviour (self-control), and self-confidence in engaging in the exercise despite the absence of supervision. Reinforcement, i.e., activities that increase the propensity for adherence during the trial and beyond the study’s lifespan, will also be addressed. 

Participants’ level of self-efficacy for engaging in lifestyle change will be assessed using a five-point Likert scale, from ‘not at all confident’ to ‘very confident. Participants will be asked to rate how confident they are to commit to engage in the exercise, irrespective of usual circumstances such as time constraints, stress, and fatigue. Assessment of self-efficacy will take place at the study onset, and at one-monthly intervals (via attendance at the supervised group sessions). With non-attendance, assessment will take place electronically. In the event of a low rating, modes of handling such situations without compromising commitment to the regime, will be given in relation to each participant’s personal circumstances. In addition, at the study outset, participants will be asked to identify any circumstances that could motivate them to comply with the exercise, as well as any perceived barriers to adherence. Any issues will be discussed, and participants will be given the opportunity to design personalised adherence strategies. The aim will be to foster self-efficacy in both groups.

After the eight-month intervention, all females in the trial arm, who have completed the study, will be invited to take part in a focus group (in groups of 8, depending on numbers who volunteer for this), to examine participants’ perceptions of the intervention. A topic guide will be used, which includes: An exploration of the perceived barriers to undertaking the exercise intervention; issues with adherence; acceptability of the intervention; adverse events; enjoyment; ratings of perceived exertion; how easily the intervention could be incorporated into lifestyle. At the end of the focus group, the topic guide will be checked to ensure that all areas had been covered. Focus groups will likely last between 45 and 60 min, although will continue until the researcher feels that data saturation has been reached. The focus groups will be audio-recorded and subsequently transcribed to facilitate analysis. Non-verbal participant behaviour will also be recorded. Focus groups will be used, since the degree of commonality and disparity of views, attitudes, beliefs, and experiences between participants can be explored. Data from the focus groups will be analysed using inductive thematic analysis (Braun & Clarke, 2006), allowing for exploration and interpretation of the relevant issues more widely (Marks & Yardley, 2004). This method will involve two of the researchers reading transcripts independently and devising their own coding, key concepts and themes. Codes and themes will be based on the research question: What is the feasibility of the eight-month exercise intervention for a potential larger study, in terms of exercise adherence, perceptions, barriers, and acceptability. All data that meet this research question will be coded. Themes will be constructed based on meaningful and coherent patterns in the data, relevant to the research questions. Analysis will be conducted by pairs of researchers, who will meet to compare their findings, and to agree a set of themes and subthemes.

All outcome measures will be taken at study outset (baseline), and at intervention end (8 months) and at 3-month follow up. In addition, data will be collected each month on: attendance at scheduled sessions; adherence to the intervention based on exercise logs; self-efficacy score; recording of adverse events including falls. 

The primary outcome measure will be BUA as measured by Quantitative Ultrasound (UBIS 5000 Diagnostic Medical Systems, Montpellier, France). The sensitivity of Quantitative Ultrasound has been investigated through meta-analysis (Babatunde, Forsyth, & Gidlow, 2012). In our laboratory, the short-term BUA measurement precision (coefficient of variation) with repositioning is 2.4%. Calibration and quality control is accomplished via an automated verification process just prior to the examination of each participant. The participant removes footwear from the dominant foot and places it in the foot well of the UBIS, which fills with water. Ultrasound waves are used to provide information on BUA, speed of sound and stiffness index. The test is non-invasive, with no ionising radiation.   

Secondary outcome measures will include: timed up-and-go test [TUG]; ground reaction force; jump height; and quality of life. The TUG is often used in studies on osteoporosis prevention as a measure of fall risk, since the test measures dynamic balance during three commonly performed functional activities: standing up, sitting down, and walking and turning (Tan et al., 2008). The test involves the participant starting in a seated position, walking 3 m, turning around, then walking back to the chair to sit down. The test has an inter-rater reliability, using ICC, of .99 (Podsiadlo & Richardson, 1991). To estimate the mechanical loading force due to the exercise, ground reaction force will be evaluated with the aid of a force plate (Advanced Mechanical Technology, Inc., AMTI). A countermovement jump test (with arms swinging naturally) will be used to assess change in jump height, using the Optojump system (Microgate S.r.l., Bolzano, Italy). Health-related quality of life will be measured using the SF-36v2 Health Survey (https://www.optum.com/solutions/life-sciences/answer-research/patient-insights/sf-health-surveys/sf-36v2-health-survey.html).

Possible confounding variables to bone accrual include history of and changes to exercise and lifestyle patterns and history of/changes to medication and health. All participants will, therefore, also complete a lifestyle and medical questionnaire consisting of: history of/current disease(s)/illnesses; previous fractures; family history of fractures/osteoporosis; current medications and dietary supplements; caffeine consumption; alcohol consumption; smoking; age of onset of menopause; history of hormone contraception; and an already validated bone-loading history questionnaire (Dolan, Williams, Ainsworth, & Shaw, 2006). All questionnaires will be self-report, but with the researcher present to aid clarity on request.
A series of ANCOVAs will be used to determine if, after adjustments for baseline values, the intervention significantly improved outcome measures.

q21.value: We will use the standard p<.05 criteria for determining if the ANOVA and the post hoc test suggest that the results are significantly different from those expected if the null hypothesis were correct. The post-hoc Bonferonni test will be used to adjust for multiple comparisons.

q22.value: Individuals will be excluded if ineligible at baseline stage and will also be excluded if they have failed to meet the minimum requirement of the exercise, which is an average of three exercise sessions per week over 8 months.

q23.value: An intention-to-treat approach will be used, whereby missing data will be estimated using a last-observation-carried forward approach.

registration_responses.q8.question: The project will be a randomised controlled trial, investigating between and within group differences pre- and post-intervention. There will be two trial arms: an intervention group and sham control group.
registration_responses.q12.question:
Data will be collected at baseline, on study completion and at 3-month follow-up. Participants will be recruited from the surrounding community via email, social media posts, word of mouth, and by visits to postmenopausal social groups. Individuals who have the desired characteristics for the study will be identified and encouraged to use their social network to recruit similar participants. 

Inclusion criteria include being postmenopausal and aged ≥50 years. Postmenopause will be defined as having had an absence of menstrual cycle for 12 months or more (Hale & Burger, 2009). 

Exclusion criteria: Volunteers will be excluded from the study if they: are using any medicated that may affect bone turnover (e.g., corticosteroids, anticonvulsants, anticoagulants, calcitonin, bisphosphonates, raloxifene, denosumab and/or anabolic agents such as parathyroid hormone and growth hormone or steroids), including hormone replacement therapy and hormone-based contraception, within 6 months of starting the study; have or have had any bone, metabolic, kidney, liver, thyroid, gastro-intestinal or hormonal disorders or cancer, that may affect bone turnover; have a close family history of osteoporosis; have sustained a low trauma fragility fracture in the past 6 months; are a heavy smoking (>20 cigarettes/day) [owing to smoking being risk factor for low bone health (Yoon, Maalouf, & Sakhaee, 2012)]; if they are already undertaking bone-specific jumping exercises or equivalent exercises; if they have an existing knee, hip or back injury or have any medical condition that would prevent them from completing the exercise. These disorders and conditions will be determined based initially through verbal interview at the recruitment stage, then confirmed through the self-reported lifestyle/medical history questionnaire at baseline. Additional exclusions at baseline testing will include: a low BUA score, i.e., estimated T score of <2.5; obesity as determined by body mass index of >35 km/m2, to minimise risk of strain or injury associated with the exercise. Participants will also not be able to undertake the bone scan if they have any foot swelling, as this can make results difficult to interpret.
registration_responses.q16.question:
Both groups (intervention and control) will complete their required programme for eight months, since 200 days (approximately 29 weeks) is the average duration of remodelling in normal trabecular bone (Eriksen, 1986), and is required for change to be detected. 

For the intervention group, participants will be required to perform 10 maximal vertical jumps, with a 10-s rest interval between each jump, using an arm swing in countermovement style on three days per week. The jumps will be performed without shoes on a hard surface. The jumps will be preceded by a warm-up lasting approximately 3 min and consisting of mobilisation exercises for the legs and lower back. The jumping protocol follows previous work in our laboratory (Babatunde & Forsyth, 2014b; Babatunde & Forsyth, 2015). Jumping will be progressed over time and in accordance with individual needs. Initially, jumping may be undertaken with the use of a handheld support (such as the back of a chair or table), should participants feel unstable. Jumps will be progressed to include multi-directional movements (jumping to the side, forwards, backwards, and diagonally). Natural progression will also occur as participants should improve their jump height with increased muscular explosiveness. Participants will be asked to fill out a simple, daily training log, stipulating when they have undertaken the exercise, in order for adherence to be assessed. 

In the control group, participants will be required to perform balance exercises. Balance is an effective treatment for avoiding falls that could potentially lead to fracture, but do not bring about a significant change in bone mineral density (de Kam et al., 2009). The balancing exercises will be progressed and varied (to ensure adherence). Initially, the use of a handheld support (such as the back of the chair) can be used. Participants will be required to balance on one leg for up to 60 seconds (2 x 60 s is equivalent in duration to the 10 jumps). This exercise will initially be progressed using time, and then by doing the following: confounding the visual fixation (e.g., head turns), changing the centre of mass (e.g. arm/leg lifts); performing the stork balance (hands on hips, knee bent and supported by standing leg); reaching in multiple directions before regaining the initial stance; closing the eyes; reducing the base of support; and a combination of these activities. The starting level of difficulty will be prescribed by the researcher, according to each participant’s functional ability. The balance exercises will be preceded by a warm-up lasting approximately 3 min and consisting of mobilisation exercises for the legs and lower back. The balance exercises are based on an existing protocol (Gianoudis et al., 2012). The purpose of the sham exercise is to foster the perception of full participation in the study, in order to decrease attrition rates, and to blind participants to the intervention. The balance exercises, although not improving bone health, could decrease the risk of fracture, making the sham control group more ethical, owing to potential improvements, and limited risks. 

To ensure quality control, digitised video clips of all exercises will be provided for the participants, who will be encouraged to perform the exercises as demonstrated on the video. The participants will be invited to one fully supervised group exercise session per month. These sessions will be used to monitor exercise quality, and to ensure progression is appropriate for each participant. Sessions will last 15-20 min. Attendance at these sessions will be monitored through registers. Apart from these supervised exercise sessions, participants will be given free choice to determine where and when they do the exercises. At the instructor-led session, training logs (Appendix 3) will be submitted. If they are unable to attend, participants will be asked to submit training logs electronically, or via post. To encourage adherence, an App will be used, which will enable weekly announcements to be posted, as well as emails and/or text reminders. Participants will be free to contact the researchers about any concerns they have during the intervention. Apart from the exercise undertaken, participants will be requested to maintain their usual exercise throughout the study. 

To improve adherence, Bandura’s Social Cognitive Theory for changing behaviour will be drawn upon. Specific constructs will include the knowledge and skills to perform the prescribed intervention, personal regulation of goal-directed health behaviour (self-control), and self-confidence in engaging in the exercise despite the absence of supervision. Reinforcement, i.e., activities that increase the propensity for adherence during the trial and beyond the study’s lifespan, will also be addressed. 

Participants’ level of self-efficacy for engaging in lifestyle change will be assessed using a five-point Likert scale, from ‘not at all confident’ to ‘very confident. Participants will be asked to rate how confident they are to commit to engage in the exercise, irrespective of usual circumstances such as time constraints, stress, and fatigue. Assessment of self-efficacy will take place at the study onset, and at one-monthly intervals (via attendance at the supervised group sessions). With non-attendance, assessment will take place electronically. In the event of a low rating, modes of handling such situations without compromising commitment to the regime, will be given in relation to each participant’s personal circumstances. In addition, at the study outset, participants will be asked to identify any circumstances that could motivate them to comply with the exercise, as well as any perceived barriers to adherence. Any issues will be discussed, and participants will be given the opportunity to design personalised adherence strategies. The aim will be to foster self-efficacy in both groups.

After the eight-month intervention, all females in the trial arm, who have completed the study, will be invited to take part in a focus group (in groups of 8, depending on numbers who volunteer for this), to examine participants’ perceptions of the intervention. A topic guide will be used, which includes: An exploration of the perceived barriers to undertaking the exercise intervention; issues with adherence; acceptability of the intervention; adverse events; enjoyment; ratings of perceived exertion; how easily the intervention could be incorporated into lifestyle. At the end of the focus group, the topic guide will be checked to ensure that all areas had been covered. Focus groups will likely last between 45 and 60 min, although will continue until the researcher feels that data saturation has been reached. The focus groups will be audio-recorded and subsequently transcribed to facilitate analysis. Non-verbal participant behaviour will also be recorded. Focus groups will be used, since the degree of commonality and disparity of views, attitudes, beliefs, and experiences between participants can be explored. Data from the focus groups will be analysed using inductive thematic analysis (Braun & Clarke, 2006), allowing for exploration and interpretation of the relevant issues more widely (Marks & Yardley, 2004). This method will involve two of the researchers reading transcripts independently and devising their own coding, key concepts and themes. Codes and themes will be based on the research question: What is the feasibility of the eight-month exercise intervention for a potential larger study, in terms of exercise adherence, perceptions, barriers, and acceptability. All data that meet this research question will be coded. Themes will be constructed based on meaningful and coherent patterns in the data, relevant to the research questions. Analysis will be conducted by pairs of researchers, who will meet to compare their findings, and to agree a set of themes and subthemes.
registration_responses.q17.question:
All outcome measures will be taken at study outset (baseline), and at intervention end (8 months) and at 3-month follow up. In addition, data will be collected each month on: attendance at scheduled sessions; adherence to the intervention based on exercise logs; self-efficacy score; recording of adverse events including falls. 

The primary outcome measure will be BUA as measured by Quantitative Ultrasound (UBIS 5000 Diagnostic Medical Systems, Montpellier, France). The sensitivity of Quantitative Ultrasound has been investigated through meta-analysis (Babatunde, Forsyth, & Gidlow, 2012). In our laboratory, the short-term BUA measurement precision (coefficient of variation) with repositioning is 2.4%. Calibration and quality control is accomplished via an automated verification process just prior to the examination of each participant. The participant removes footwear from the dominant foot and places it in the foot well of the UBIS, which fills with water. Ultrasound waves are used to provide information on BUA, speed of sound and stiffness index. The test is non-invasive, with no ionising radiation.   

Secondary outcome measures will include: timed up-and-go test [TUG]; ground reaction force; jump height; and quality of life. The TUG is often used in studies on osteoporosis prevention as a measure of fall risk, since the test measures dynamic balance during three commonly performed functional activities: standing up, sitting down, and walking and turning (Tan et al., 2008). The test involves the participant starting in a seated position, walking 3 m, turning around, then walking back to the chair to sit down. The test has an inter-rater reliability, using ICC, of .99 (Podsiadlo & Richardson, 1991). To estimate the mechanical loading force due to the exercise, ground reaction force will be evaluated with the aid of a force plate (Advanced Mechanical Technology, Inc., AMTI). A countermovement jump test (with arms swinging naturally) will be used to assess change in jump height, using the Optojump system (Microgate S.r.l., Bolzano, Italy). Health-related quality of life will be measured using the SF-36v2 Health Survey (https://www.optum.com/solutions/life-sciences/answer-research/patient-insights/sf-health-surveys/sf-36v2-health-survey.html).

Possible confounding variables to bone accrual include history of and changes to exercise and lifestyle patterns and history of/changes to medication and health. All participants will, therefore, also complete a lifestyle and medical questionnaire consisting of: history of/current disease(s)/illnesses; previous fractures; family history of fractures/osteoporosis; current medications and dietary supplements; caffeine consumption; alcohol consumption; smoking; age of onset of menopause; history of hormone contraception; and an already validated bone-loading history questionnaire (Dolan, Williams, Ainsworth, & Shaw, 2006). All questionnaires will be self-report, but with the researcher present to aid clarity on request.
registration_responses.q19.question: A series of ANCOVAs will be used to determine if, after adjustments for baseline values, the intervention significantly improved outcome measures.
